title: Now Susan Searle, chairman of Woodford Patient Capital, faces calls to quit
text:
The chairman of Woodford Patient Capital Trust is under mounting pressure to quit over her handling of the crisis engulfing the disgraced fund manager.

Susan Searle has been accused of 'failing investors' by taking so long to get rid of Neil Woodford from the stock market-listed fund that bears his name.

The Patient Capital board finally this week appointed blue-blooded City firm Schroders to run the trust – but only after shareholders had lost as much as 75 per cent of their investment.

Firing line: Susan Searle has been accused of 'failing investors' by taking so long to get rid of Neil Woodford from the stock market-listed fund that bears his name

One expert last night said Searle 'had failed in her job and should be sacked', while former pensions minister Baroness Altmann said the board's role in the debacle should be investigated as part of a wider probe into what had happened.

Critics also raised concerns about the 'cosy relationship' that appeared to exist between the board and Woodford, and questioned whether he had been given 'special treatment'.

Savers face huge losses, with those who invested £10,000 when the trust launched in April 2015 now sitting on around £3,600.

Although the appointment of Schroders has offered some hope, Justin Modray, founder of financial advice site Candid Money, raised fears it may be too late to turn a profit for many investors.

He said: 'Ultimately this is the responsibility of the board's chair. She [Searle] has failed in her job and should be sacked.'

Critics raised concerns that the relationship between the board and Woodford was too close.

As well as being chairman of Patient Capital, Searle has sat on the boards of companies Woodford invested in, including start-up investor Mercia Technologies, gene editing firm Horizon Discovery and health company Benchmark Holdings.

City commentator David Buik, of trading firm Core Spreads, described getting Schroders to run the trust as a 'real coup', but added: 'The board of Patient Capital looked too cosy and incestuous. Searle should have already gone. The buck stops at the top.'

Searle was one of only two board members to survive following the shake-up triggered by the suspension of Woodford's flagship Equity Income fund in June.

Investors were barred from withdrawing their cash from the fund – even as the value of their savings tumbled and Woodford continued to charge a total of £65,000 in fees a day.

The crisis at Equity Income culminated in the collapse of Woodford's investment empire last week. Altmann said: 'It is possible that the board did not ask enough questions and did not put the manager under as much pressure and scrutiny as it would have done had it been a different manager. You have to ask what the board was doing.'

Patient Capital Trust declined to comment.
